article.headline: BYU 67, Air Force 61
article.story: PROVO, Utah (AP) -- Brigham Young spoiled Air Force's bid at a first conference championship and kept the Cougars' own slim hopes alive. The Cougars, who opened the Mountain West Conference season 2-4, won their sixth straight by rallying to beat first-place Air Force 67-61 Monday night. Rafael Araujo and Mark Bigelow scored 21 points apiece to lead BYU (18-7, 8-4), which needs win its final two games and have Air Force (19-5, 9-2) lose two of its final three for a share of the MWC regular-season title. "They're a great team and it's going to be tough for them to lose two more games, but we're still in the hunt," said Bigelow, who scored 15 in the second half and finished with five assists. "We're on a six-game winning streak and hopefully we get two more." Air Force could have locked up the No. 1 seed in the Mountain West tournament next month with a win, which would have given the Falcons their first-ever sweep of both Utah and BYU. The Falcons beat the Utes 59-57 on Saturday. "We did our job this weekend," Air Force coach Joe Scott said. "No matter what we're going to have a winning road record in this league and that says a lot and most importantly, I think we got better this weekend." Air Force has UNLV, San Diego State and Wyoming remaining. One victory gets the Falcons their first-ever 20-win season, but they want the league title much more. "We played well and had our chance to win the game, but tonight we didn't make plays toward the end of the game like we did in Utah, but we definitely had the effort out there," said A.J. Kuhle, who had nine points for the Falcons. "That's the way a conference is. It's hard to get road wins, especially at BYU." In the end, Air Force just couldn't stop Araujo, who also had eight rebounds. The 6-foot-11, 280-pound senior was at least 2 inches taller and 50 pounds heavier than any of the Falcons and BYU used the bulky Brazilian to wear down Air Force. The Cougars shot 82.4 percent (14-for-17) in the second half. "We missed some shots in the first half, in the second half we were making them and that goes a long way," Bigelow said. "We're on a six-game winning streak and hopefully we get two more." The Cougars have Utah and UNLV remaining on the schedule. BYU hasn't lost since falling at Utah 64-56 on Jan. 31. "It was a sense of urgency that maybe we didn't have," coach Steve Cleveland said. "We decided not to forget those kinds of experience and come back and remembered them as we entered the second half of conference play." Nick Welch led Air Force with 16 points, Tim Keller scored 14 and Antoine Hood finished with 10 points and seven rebounds. After going nearly the first five minutes of the second half without a field goal, the Cougars made 6 of 7 from the field while turning an eight-point deficit into a 43-41 lead. Bigelow scored seven straight for BYU on two jumpers and a three-point play to tie it at 41, then Jake Shoff drove for a layup that gave the Cougars their first lead since 15-14. BYU extended the lead to 52-45 before the Falcons started to make a comeback after Kuhle was fouled hard by Araujo with 5:38 remaining. Air Force coach Joe Scott was livid at the foul, which Kuhle came up from with a bloody mouth and had to leave for a few minutes. It seemed to spark the Falcons, who started to rally when Matt McCraw came in to shoot for Kuhle and went 1-for-2 from the line, followed by two free throws by Welch and Keller's three-point play to cut the lead to 54-51. Welch made two more free throws to pull Air Force to 56-55 with 2:33 remaining, but the Falcons couldn't overtake the Cougars. Araujo scored on a layup, Bigelow made two free throws and Mike Rose was all alone under the basket after BYU broke Air Force's press to put the Cougars up 62-56. The Falcons led 26-23 at halftime after using their quickness and some sharp outside shooting to outscore the larger Cougars. Air Force was 6-for-13 from 3-point range while holding the Cougars to 0-for-5 from beyond the arc.
